awd_titl_txt: Endocrine, genetic and epigenetic mechanisms of coping with environmental change in tropical birds
awd_abstract_narration:
How do organisms cope with uncertainty in their environment? Understanding how organisms cope physiologically with naturally variable environments will be important for predicting organismal responses, including those in humans, to increasingly unpredictable environments characterized by frequent extreme weather events like droughts and floods. And since coping mechanisms themselves, short-term physiological and behavioral responses, respond to environmental variation over longer time periods, a comparative approach is needed to fully understand how organisms have historically responded to climatic uncertainty. To determine how vertebrates adapt to and cope with environmental variation at the physiological and molecular level, this study will simultaneously explore patterns of genetic and epigenetic variation in genes of birds that underlie the stress response and the entire genome across an ecological gradient in Kenya, and then relate this variation to patterns of gene expression in naturally variable and experimentally-controlled climates. This study will train high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, in the field and lab. Training will emphasize cutting-edge, integrative tools that are transferable across disciplines. Researchers will work closely with a grassroots Kenyan conservation organization to educate rural schoolchildren on conservation and wildlife through a series of teaching modules and public representations. Finally, researchers will present the results of their work locally around New York City and in popular articles aimed at a diverse audience.

One of the primary ways that vertebrates cope physiologically with environmental variability is through changes in the hypothalamo-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, the neuroendocrine system that controls reactions to stress. The HPA axis encompasses a cascade of hormones, receptors, and other molecules, each of which may respond to different types and timescales of environmental variation. Although understanding how the HPA axis responds to environmental variability is important for determining how organisms will cope with environmental uncertainty because it is one of the first ways that vertebrates respond to environmental stressors, many other physiological, endocrine, and molecular pathways are also impacted by environmental stressors. Therefore, a genome-wide approach that links molecular mechanisms and adaptive genetic and epigenetic variation more broadly to physiological function will be necessary to understand how animals adapt to and cope with environmental uncertainty. The objective of this study is to determine how environmental variation influences adaptive genetic (DNA sequence) and epigenetic variation (DNA methylation), gene function (mRNA expression), and physiological responses (hormone activity) to shape particular phenotypes in populations of free-living superb starlings (Lamprotornis superbus) sampled across a broad-scale ecological gradient in sub-Saharan Africa encompassing some of the most unpredictable climatic zones in the world. Building upon long-term data in African starlings, and using a series of newly-established populations along an ecological gradient in Kenya, this work will allow researchers to begin to understand how environmentally-induced selection pressures shape the molecular mechanisms, adaptive evolutionary responses, and coping strategies that vertebrates use to live with environmental uncertainty.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand how environmental variation shapes the evolution, function, and plastic expression of the vertebrate hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA or stress) axis as well as the genome more broadly in birds by determining how: (1) environmental variation shapes the evolution and plasticity of the HPA axis; (2) genetic and epigenetic variation across the genome are related and shaped by environmental variation; and (3) adaptive genetic and epigenetic variation interact with climate to influence gene expression in both the HPA axis and across the genome. We did this by studying adaptive genetic and epigenetic variation, gene function, and endocrine physiological in populations of free-living birds sampled across a broad-scale ecological gradient in Kenya encompassing some of the most unpredictable climatic zones in the world.

Although glucocorticoid (stress) hormones respond rapidly to social and ecological stressors, we showed that among-population variation in baseline glucocorticoids was most strongly shaped by long-term mean annual precipitation, whereas variation in stress-induced levels was poorly explained by precipitation on any timescale. However, adrenal sensitivity, quantified via hormone injection, was shaped by long-term precipitation and highest in unpredictable environments. Together, these results suggest that among-population variation in glucocorticoids can be best explained by environmental variation at timescales that extend beyond the lives of individual starlings rather than simply the environmental conditions that they experience over a period of days to weeks. Patterns of long-term precipitation variation may thus represent a microevolutionary selective pressure shaping the endocrine stress axis across populations and influencing how individuals cope with environmental change.

To determine how environmentally sensitive (adaptive) genes might evolve, we compared patterns of DNA methylation in different starling populations across the environmental gradient. We found that the majority of differentially methylated genes show the potential for adaptive epigenetic programming, with lower methylation in drier and more variable environments. Differentially methylated genes that show consistent patterns across the ecological gradient include those related to immune function, cardiac function, metabolism, and to a lesser degree, the stress response. Many of the genes that we found to be differentially methylated across the environmental gradient are the same or closely related to those that have been identified in a variety of mammalian studies to be associated with desert adaptation. These previous studies have all looked at genetic variation, and to our knowledge, ours is the first to examine how DNA methylation is related to environmental variation at this scale. We continue to analyze this dataset and are examining genetic variation in these same regions of the genome. Ultimately, we will combine our DNA methylation results with our gene expression and genetic variation results for a more complete story of how genetic and epigenetic variation interact with climate to influence adaptive coping in unpredictable environments. 

In terms of intellectual merit, our work has helped determine how, in an evolutionary context, organisms adapt to and cope with environmental variation at the physiological and molecular level. It has shown how patterns of long-term precipitation variation can shape the endocrine stress axis across populations of vertebrates, and how epigenetic change in environmentally sensitive regions of the genome may underlie adaptation to harsh and unpredictable environments. 

In terms of broader impacts, this project helped contribute to the education and training of numerous American and Kenyan students at a variety of academic stages, the vast majority of whom were female. We also worked with the Northern Kenya Conservation Clubs, a grassroots conservation organization that educates rural school children at 12 schools near the study site, to develop modules and activities related to starling behavior and environmental change. The concepts underlying this project were presented to undergraduate students in an introductory course that all first-year students take at Columbia, as well as to prospective students in recruiting lectures. The themes and concepts in this project were also highlighted through readings, fieldwork, and fieldtrips in the areas of this study in an undergraduate field course taught as part of semester abroad program in Kenya. Results from this work were presented in a series of online seminars that are available on YouTube to the broader public.
